4269.Review: This great tequila defies odds by proving how wood and agave can coexist without wood dominating. Flavors of charred wood, agave, pepper, coffee, citrus, nutty sherry, peat, caramel, and chocolate. Bourbon, rum, brandy, and tequila in 1.

4270.Review: citrus nose. oak and pepper flavor. smooth finish

4271.Review: Tastes of cloves,maple, dark chocolate, tobacco , oak very complex taste that leaves me wanting more. Rich aroma of black cherry .  Long velvety finish smooth on the tongue moving  through peppery to earthy ending on a sweet note.

4272.Review: Very woody and delicious - drank this at the Semi Finals Rugby World Cup 2015 - appropriate tequila

4273.Review: Very dark color. One of the greatest tequilas/extra anejos in the world. So smooth it's dangerous..

4275.Review: One of my favorites, great sipping with cigar. Good hearty aroma along with great after taste

4277.Review: This is a true XA and harder to find now. So much going on. Agave, mocha, cherry, figs, blood orange, leather, butterscotch, etc. I usually find it for under 60. Must have for any legit Tequilero.

4278.Review: Nose of whiskey, caramel, vanilla, roasted nuts and some alcohol. Taste of caramel, spice, roasted nuts and vanilla. Very nice.

4279.Review: Older clown nose bottle but still vibrant. Quite whiskey forward, today this would be an XA and has aromas of barrel spice, caramel and agave. The bourbon notes on the nose are very apparent on sipping. Short finish holds this back a bit for me.

4280.Review: Find this lil gem again in my lil favorite mom and pop I love this juice it is one of the nicest tequila I have experienced and they have 3 more bottles waiting on me calling my name!! Lol

4281.Review: Owned this bottle for years, decided to go ahead & finish it off, fearing it will soon go bad. Terrific tequila, but cannot recall what I paid. Decent nose, nice vanilla notes with caramel on the back end of the palette.

4282.Review: Aroma: Sweet scent, with anise, cinnamon, and alcohol.Flavor: Sweet across the palate, with a strong mixture of anise and cinnamon.Finish: Identical to the flavor, almost no bite.Overall: Strongly suspect that there are additives. Still, it’s a nice dessert sipping tequila for after dinner. Tastes like it has an entire cinnamon stick in each bottle.

4283.Review: NOPE VANILLA SYRUP Wretched Trash Don’t do it

4284.Review: On the sweeter side but very smooth

4285.Review: Does everyone taste this in Cabo?Decent but lets not get carried away with ratings in the 90s.

4286.Review: One of three bottles I own.  Dark in color almost cola like with faint plum and copper tints.  Very odd aroma of burnt gas/tar.  A hint of raisin with little agave.  Entry is similar to the nose, but quickly turns to cedar chest like flavor.  Once opened up, the cedar is followed by a moderate smoke.  Very complex and not as sweet as others have noted, at least in this barrel.  Very different than other XAs.  Not great, but not bad.  Hope my other bottles are better.  C

4287.Review: Strong licorice flavor and Wood notes. Let it breathe and it gets better.

4289.Review: This one is definitely an outlier in the world of Extra Anejo. Heavy, resinous, pine tree scent like a car air freshener. Aromas dominated by licorice, anise, and tarragon. It reminds me of Sambuca minus the three coffee beans. Good thing I LOVE black jelly beans. There is also pronounced Damiana character to it. Overall, I really like this one for its uniqueness and complexity. I will definitely keep it in the line up. If Tequila and Sambuca had a love child - this would be it!

4290.Review: Different bottle but excellent. Priced around $70. Carmel, Vanilla, and fruit flavor. Great on the nose.

4291.Review: Aroma is all barrel and no agave. Taste is unusual and sweet, once again heavy wood with strong prune. Finish has a little bite with cough syrup aftertaste. Seems more like cognac than tequila.

4292.Review: pepper and cherry aroma! awsome flavour and finish. able to  feel aged feeling well.

4293.Review: Just a phenomenal bottle. It's particularly good for people coming from fine whiskeys, but everyone seemed to love it.The agave is certainly evident, but also not too strong.  Definitely one of my favorite sipping tequilas, and it goes fantastically with a light bodied cigar as well.

4294.Review: This is an amazing concoction has a somewhat sweet smell and brings to mind vanilla and caramel. Meant to be sipped, preferably in a small snifter, on its own. Perfect for after dinner or just relaxing with good friends. The price is excellent for the quality you’re getting. My current go-to affordable tequila - yum!

4295.Review: I love tequila, On my list it has always been Patron, Don Julio Reposado and 1942 until I tried Chula Parranda for the first time on April, 2018 in Guadalajara Mexico. It is the best tequila I've ever had! It is my Top and Only choice of tequila! In my opinion, it is priced very low for the amazing quality and care they put into their making of tequila and their bottles! "Thank You for creating this Amazing Tequila, CHULA PARRANDA!"

4296.Review: Very good value, with strong grass and caramel flavor taste. I love it.

4297.Review: The vanilla and caramel taste is exceptional. Wonderful product.

4299.Review: I am Always going to get this brand.

4300.Review: there is an interesting peppery under tone that gives way to an incredibly sweet finish that ruins what might be a good Tequila. bought this on a recent trip to MX wish i hadn't. I'll let it sit, see if the sweetness subsides if not I'll see if i can make interesting drinks out of it or drop it in the trashupdate: I've tried this tequila on 4 different occasions and like it less each time i drink it. i eventually poured it down the sink. it is the worst tequila I've ever put in my mouth... I'd drink Jose Cuervo mixto before this monstrousity

4301.Review: What a great tasting and sipping Tequila.  Love the Vanilla and Caramel taste  and it goes great with a nice Cigar. Is not too sweet and it leaves a great taste in my mouth.

4302.Review: Maybe this was a bad lot, but I felt this was way too sweet. It seemed to overpower all other flavours. Will definitely re-assess when I have another taste of this.

4304.Review: I LOVE this tequila.  It is slightly smoky, hints of caramel and barrel with a touch of sweet.  Not Cava de oro sweet, but just a perfect balance.  It is my favorite right now and hard to get.  First tried in Cabo and no one carries it in AZ or CA so I had to have it shipped in.

4305.Review: Aged in whiskey barrel, not to strong

4306.Review: Complex, very different from other extra anejo's. Will keep in collection.

4307.Review: Amazing aroma and a middle and end to top. Complex flavors from the wood barrel.

4308.Review: Nose:   Tropical floral nose with berry/cherry fruitiness. Soft wood notes and agave. Flavor:   Vanilla, white pepper, cloves and allspice. Finish:   Lengthy butterscotch, vanilla, pepper finish with a hint of bitterness.

4309.Review: This anejo has a beautiful, soft butterscotch flavour with a deep golden straw colour.  The finish is a medium, and very pleasant.  Very soft on the nose.Note that this review comes 6 months after opening the bottle, which Iâ€™m sure has softened the tasting notes considerably.

4310.Review: Thinner letter metal label. Warm cooked agave, cinnamon, mocha, jalapeno, orange zest, roasted nuts, ginger... I need more of these older bastards!

4311.Review: Aroma had hints of agave, wood, and was very floral almost like perfume. The taste had some baked baked agave, a little vanilla, and a hint of caramel. Finish was medium to long with oak, but it had a little bit of a bitter finish.

4312.Review: Did not enjoy this one. Something musky/mildewy about it from start to finish. The finish was extremely flat. Could be a bad bottle.

4313.Review: This old school tequila has aromas of anise, caramel and mint along with fruit- guyabana?Delicious with nice mouthfeel and minty finish.

4314.Review: I got several bottles of this in Mexico and still have one unopened.

4316.Review: The aromas from the bottle are amazing, So different to what you get in the glass.

4317.Review: Lote Yr 2004 Paper label tall bottle MX Version

4318.Review: On the nose, Light oak, agave, and fruit. A little bit of berries. Canteloupe, or maybe honeydew, some type of melon for sure. Beautiful aroma, one of my favorite notes and I rarely get it. On the palate, Intense flavor. Spices, minerals, agave. Definitely get the oak, definitely get the earthiness. It’s got a nice balanced sweetness, and a bit of vanilla. I swear I’m tasting almond and maybe butter, but sweet. A tiny bit of mint in the finish for me. Many people consider this the weak spot of the Terralta line but I would have to completely disagree. This is fantastic, full of flavor. I almost feel like the reposado is more subdued in comparison. The first sip was an exposition of flavor and at $51 at my local spot, I’ll keep this in stock forever.

4319.Review: What a fantastic light and clean Anejo by Felipe Camarena.

4320.Review: Well balanced with sweet cooked agave, alcohol and light wood

4321.Review: Oak, honeydew, agave, vanilla, pepper, cinnamon, a touch of smoke. Medium finish with a rich coat. Excellent!

4322.Review: Slight oak, dry wood and spicy aroma. Ripe plum, a bit of milk candy, and some melon.Wood taste slighty overcomes the agave taste in this one, although wood taste is really balanced and not overwhelming due to the exhausted bourbon casks used to age the tequila. In the aftertaste, rich agave taste richly appears in an underlying layer: first I get cooked agave and then raw agave comes to scene. Not the average woody, vanilla and caramel taste on this one, and that is just great!

4323.Review: Aroma : Cooked agave and apricot predominate here. There is also some brine and light oak. Light earth as well.Taste : Light agave here with some oak. A small degree of brine here as well. Peppery with some almond and caramel. Full bodied.Finish : Long with stronger notes of anoak and caramel barrel influence.

4324.Review: Nose:   Full on agave. Ripe peach, apricot and berries. Undercurrent of barrel spice - very light oak!Flavor:   Coats your mouth with silky vanilla, almond and jerk-like spices. A nice pepper sensation. A hint of brine and cured cheese. A slight tongue numbing, satisfying finish.

4326.Review: This has some really nice flavor with caramel and oak along with agave spice of white pepper and moderate alcohol. Nice

4327.Review: Phenomenal cooked agave, vanilla and oak aroma, w

4328.Review: Very sippable strong barrel notes with a hint of peach thrown in. Not my favorite anejo but definitely with a try.

4329.Review: Everything is a bit muted here.  Nose is good with caramel, agave, and some anise.  To be fair, the bottle is brand new so an eventual update will happen.  I do appreciate the muted barrel influence, but this has a time and place.  Lighter than many repos, if you’re in the mood for barrel, then don’t seek this.  It lost so much of it’s oily intensity and viscosity compared to the blanco.  Right into the barrel wall.  This is very good, but I think you have to be in the mood for a light anejo.  However, he found a way to not lose the agave, tough to do with an anejo.

4330.Review: Honey, wet slate, varnished oak, ripe banana, citrus nose. Very well balanced, all of the flavors blend together into one very nice, hard to describe taste. Restrained and light, the barrel notes are strictly complementary to the agave. Could be fooled into thinking this is a rich reposado, though the buttery notes give it much more depth than a typical repo.

4331.Review: On the nose you’re greeted with oak but the edge has been rounded off with vanilla, there is some cooked agave and stone fruit that’s balanced as well. On entry you get the sweetness of the stone fruit followed by the warming of the vanilla, oak and some cinnamon.on the finish you’re left with the oak and some lingering vanilla, great balanced añejo between agave and barrel.

4332.Review: The light straw color is lighter than many reposados which we know is Felipe’s goal to minimize barrel influence and retain an agave presence which I like in aged tequilas.

4333.Review: Aromas: Butterscotch, cinnamon, orange peel and earth.Taste: Baking spice, butter and cooked agave.Finish: Minerals, smoke, dried fruits and white pepper.

4334.Review: This is Terralta! Fantastic. crisp, still has agave touch with the light aging. I tend to prefer this over heavy oak. But time and place, and this one is perfect for me right now.

4335.Review: Melon, cooked agave very little wood a little vanilla very pleasant, very unassuming bottleGet it if you can

4336.Review: Aroma, light but definite agave, burnt brown sugar, and vanilla tones. Flavor, kind of faint at first followed by burnt brown sugar, agave, wood, and anise. Finish a touch hot for its aging but overall a good sipper and sharer (meaning it's one I won't be hoarding)

4337.Review: Terralta Añejo lot 1Lote: LT0001A40 (Oct 13, 2016)Date tasted: June 17, 2022 Nose: agave, fruit, peach, a little oak, pepper Taste: sweet agave, vanilla, oak, slight pepper Finish: sweet agave slight oak and pepper, warmth. very nice finish Other: This is an old bottle with about 1/4 left in the bottle. it was still very good and well balanced. Nice legs, viscosity is not too thick not watery. Just right. Another easy sipper. smell the glass when it's empty. Caramel on the nose!

4338.Review: Agave, fruit, earthy, and light oak on the nose. Very soft on the palate. Brine, agave, light carmel, and fruit notes on the palate. Very uneventful for an Anejo. Not bad but a little light on flavor. Would not think it was an anejo if I did not pour it myself.

4339.Review: Decent Anejo, but not as much flavor as I'd hoped. Many better options out there, including several from NOM 1579.

4340.Review: Terralta's Anjeo is light, crisp, and affordable.  Give this time to open up. Aroma: Immediately hit with a light bourbon barrel char. Cooked agave, cinnamon and white pepper follow suit.  Notes of apricot/peach, red berries, a touch of vanilla and orange citrus. Taste:  Dry mouthfeel, yet silky.   There is a cinnamon warth that builds through the finish.  Cooked agave, a touch of almond and a slight briney bite. Flavors slowly develop into salted caramel along with vanilla and black pepper.Finish: Long. Salty carmel, cracked pepper and cinnamon warmth play well together.

4341.Review: Very good!  The nose begins with agave and oak  The mouthfeel is clean water which is refreshing.  There is light pepper and agave  which finished with some more oak, agave and just a bit of pepper and sweetness.  A nicely done anejo.

4343.Review: Beautiful mineral and citrus qualities. Bold rich flavors of lemon/lime citrus, vanilla bean, custard, agave…. Oily mouthfeel. Excellent!

4344.Review: On the nose i get like the sweetness from the agave but also a fruitiness like cherry’s. On the palate, i still get a sweetness, white pepper,  the American oak towards the end.

4345.Review: Subtle nose but with plenty of Terralta goodness on the palate. The barrel influence is just right. Just can’t find any fault with the Terralta lineup!

4347.Review: Nose: Agave forward with citrus and oakFlavor: this is a true Tequila,  great agave taste, nice subtle oak, very smooth finish with a refreshing slight burn, but barelyGreat value!!

4348.Review: Outstanding añejo!! barrel influence hits exactly the sweet spot between the agave and the oak. One can’t do any better. Apricot, orange peel, sweet agave, peach.  No need to go for the extra anejo, True craftsmanship, nothing else to say...

4349.Review: cooked agave, spices, citrus, wood, butterscotchoak, agave, vanilla, butter

4350.Review: pine, spice, apricot on nose. flavor is obviously cooked agave, oak (not overpowering), vanilla. then the cinnamon, pepper, spice. olive and slight lactic develops in finish

4351.Review: took 3 times before I could taste agave. wood earth minerals maybe some spice. nice long finish. my least favorite terralta

4352.Review: This was not the quality I was expecting from this brand. Not much oak taste, not a lot of agave. A little too much alcohol taste.

4353.Review: Nose: cooked agave, tree fruit of peaches and plums, orange zest and blossoms, fresh crack black pepper, and cardamom Flavor: sweet cooked agave, honey, cinnamon, nutmeg, cardamom and a hint of butterscotch Finish: start’s with some agave sweetness and moves to white pepper spice and light bitterness

4354.Review: This is an infused 100% Blue Weber Agave Blanco. They take 1000 liters of 100 proof Blanco and then they place 21 kgs of cooked Blue Weber into cotton bags that are then seeped for 5 days. It’s then filtered to remove particles and proofed to 40% abv - 80 proof. The color comes from the infusion. This tequila isn’t aged nor rested in oak. Originally this was going to be an extension to the Tequila Ocho line but it’s an independent brand with 2 other infusions. If you have never smelled cooked agave from a horno, this is the closest experience that you can have without actually smelling cooked agaves at a distillery. It’s cooked agave sweetness. It’s buttery and one note but that one note is excellent. Surprise! The buttery cooked agave smacks your palate. It’s a nice rustic agave taste. There’s some minerality and pepper but it’s mostly agave. It has a pleasant medium finish.

4355.Review: Presents the most amazing aromas when opened and poured. Sweet roast agave permeates the area reminding me of the oven spaces at La Alteña. Pepper on the palate is accentuated by the infusion of the agave azul. Side by side with the original labeled El Primero Curado it's hard to distinguish much difference between the 2013 issued original and the 2019 release. I was anticipating perhaps a small amount of oxidation from the older bottle but it's not there. Perhaps a bit more overall depth to the newer bottle. I wish these had a wider distribution being a one off Ocho product and I look forward to the next wave from Los Alambiques.

4356.Review: Agave, vegetal, pepper, cinnamon, and honey. Wasn’t expecting much but am pleasantly surprised!

4357.Review: Lot BC 008 Bottled 02/09/2019Straw colored. Nose:   You are immediately greeted with the aroma of mature roasted agave fresh from the horno. There is a panoply of sweet and lively spices mingled with light colored tree fruit and orange peel. A faint nuance of woodiness and warm butterscotch. Some earthy cellar notes, and a dash of black pepper. Flavor:   Bold agave is congruous to the nosing. The flavor carries an incense quality that is tough to pigeonhole.  Honey sweetness and sensation on the palate - with kicked up pepper, cinnamon, nutmeg and cardamom heat. Really quite a departure from my experience. Finish:   Creamy butterscotch undercurrent, with pepper counterpoint and trace bitterness. On the sweeter side - wouldn’t want to drink it all night.

4358.Review: Cupreata (Agave Azul)$53 USD (Ferment and Still)Lot BC-011 11/05/2022Overall: Sensational and easy to sip, but is on the sweeter side.  The Agave Azuel starts off with the wonderful qualities of Tequila Ocho's blanco line and adds a warm, earthy, and barrel aged presence - without the barrel aging.  Bold cooked agave.Soft fruits, soft baking spice, and truly enjoyable.  Rather than piece together my thoughts, I'll simply tell you to read Don Heiser's notes - he is spot on.

4359.Review: Had all three, as someone stated, very similar in profile/flavors with sameness probably due to process and differences due to agaves used in infusion. Aromas of strong cooked agave, cinnamon, vanilla, spices and faint caramel. Flavor of cooked agave, burnt sugar, some jalapeño/oily residue with certain sweetness. A nice change of pace and good conversation piece for sure. A must for any collection.

4360.Review: Update: Glencairn glass; aroma muted: taste: agave silky mouthfeel; no alcohol burn on the finish; ends with sweetness; very easy to drink - no change to scoreUpdate: same aroma; flavor is layered with pepper and baked agave. +1 pointAroma: sweet baked agave, some cinnamon Taste: lot going on here; some good heat and burn. Going to have to come back to this one for fair review…

4361.Review: Nice agave loads of anise, agave, pepper.  Different but nice

4362.Review: I didn’t know what to expect from this with its infusion of agave but it’s pretty decent. Quite a smoky taste but not bad at all.

4363.Review: A complex nose of agave, fruit (plum?), pepper, honey and alcohol in the background. Same is true on the palate. Not quite sure about this one, first tasting …

4364.Review: Very agave forward nose with some oak, carmel, light spices. Taste matches the nose very well with a lingering finish

4365.Review: Aroma... Vanilla and light oak Flavor... sweet agave and vanilla mild pepperFinish... clean with a lingering vanilla and a slight alcohol bite

4366.Review: Agave oak and pepper. Finish is a little harsh.

4367.Review: Beautiful. Cascahuin from the moment you sniff it and take a sip. But then, it surprises you with sweetness and smoke that is not very typical of Cascahuin. A great one for sure.

4369.Review: Oak and cooked agave notes coupled with hints of vanilla and smokiness from resting in mezcal barrels. Very nice mouthfeel, light at first but then the agave and smokiness shine through. A near perfect mix of a reposado-like finish, that ends on a blend of slightly smoky mezcal notes, sweet agave, vanilla, and spice. It drinks like a high end, slightly sweet mezcal.

4370.Review: I went into this without knowing what to expect or the story behind this liquid. It blew my mind as I was expecting a standard Blanco. As soon as it hit my glass I knew something special was coming. I thought it was the background causing my glass to show a tint but sure enough it's straw colored. Wtf?! Nose- Agave, oak (?!), basil, earth, sweet fruit. Smoked meat. Now I'm making sure I have the right sample.Taste- A religious experience. Smokey iodine, agave, butter, anise, caramel, and faint vanilla (I'm guessing from the oak).Mouth feel is rich for a Blanco Finish- The scotch-like notes fall off quickly, leaving a spicy end to my experience. I don't understand what just happened.

4371.Review: Nose:Very sweet agave notes. A touch of pineapple, black pepper clear as day.  Very faint mesquite. Very pleasurable on the nose, top 10 for me personally, I could smell this all day. Palate:Sharp agave instantly, the pepper on the nose definitely comes through. Definitely some heat but it plays well with that Sharp agave kick. I’m getting something that reminds me of Fortaleza for some reason. Minerals on the finish, but not very prominent in the initial tasting for me. A little buttery, but not a sweet butter. Very, very interesting. Definitely more of that mesquite on the finish for me. Verdict:Wow, very good stuff here. This is something I’d definitely love to show off to people who haven’t had a more interesting tequila. The light mesquite and the clear pepper notes make this one very, very interesting for me. I’m definitely a fan, hoping the rest of the ArteNOM lineup is this good.

4372.Review: NOM 1123, Lot 43,. Light straw-golden color. Aroma: Azahar, clay, smoke, agave, plum, roast pineapple, baking spice, cinnamon, butter.  Palate: oily, cinnamon, espadín agave-peppery, hot butter, almond, smoke, black pepper, terroir, anise. Finish is long on center of mouth, oily, mineral, almond, agave, and hot cinnamon. Tongue numbness. Lots of pearls on the glass. Easy to sip!

4373.Review: The lightest straw color. Sweet nose, light baking spices and cooked agave with very subtle caramel notes. The booze makes itself present although not a burner. Buttery, round mouth feel. A faint touch of butterscotch. Ever so minor touch of smoke I actually feel like I was searching for it rather than it being a true representation. A little spice at the end. - heat runs through an excellent finish and let’s you know it’s got presence.

4374.Review: Agave forward on the nose.. some elements of smoke... slight fruitiness .... a different blanco tequila... coked agave on the mouth.  Excellent

4375.Review: The nose greets you prior to each sip and then the pleasant flavors reward your decision to partake this spirit. The finish is a flavorful mix of sweet and savory peppers. This is a unique blanco that’s rested in brady barrels that previously contained an Oaxacan mezcal. What an interesting tequila. The nose is a nice mixture of light floral sweetness and some warm earthy notes like hay and minerals with a hint of morning campfire smoke. It’s complex. I first get sweet cooked agave and then some warm baking spices immediately follow. There’s a pleasant warming tingle from the 43% abv that lingers into the finish. This product begs you to take sip after sip.

4376.Review: Beautiful sweet agave nose. little smokiness to it from the Mezcal barrels and pepper in the flavor but a nice treat at a great price with minimal heat for being a HP.  Everything coming out of NOM1123 is excellent and this is another fantastic addition to the ArteNom lineup

4377.Review: Wait, this straw colored tequila is a blanco?! ArteNOM 1123 is doing things the old way, aging in used oak barrels for 3-4 weeks—and mezcal barrels at that! I’m picking up aromas of agave, pineapple, baking spices, smoke, straw, and cider. I taste vanilla, almond, licorice, cinnamon, pepper, smoke, and flowers. The flavors span the spectrum, making this really balanced. Simply excellent!

4378.Review: Light golden color, not your typical blanco, exceptional aromas and flavors. Winner

4379.Review: very unique tequila rested 28 days in used Mezcal Brandy barrels. This has it all

4380.Review: The latest ArteNOM, AN 1123 Blanco Historico is a blanco made from lower brix (24) agave from the Valle and then finished for 3 to 4 weeks in brandy barrels that had previously held Oaxacan mezcal. I remember I read it was Don Amado who had used the barrels prior. Big fragrant nose from the resting of this now straw colored Cascahuin made distillate in the barrels. A bit of sour cider notes with caramelized agave carried by 43% ABV juice turns into an very aggresive spiciness on intake, slamming the tongue with sharp flavors from the ethanol, the resting, the base blanco itself. Man, I want to taste this at still/barrel proof if this what 43% tastes like. Finish is quite long at the center of the tongue, minutes long really. A worthy addition

4381.Review: Hints of Cascahuin on the nose! Raw honey in the mid-palate, the creamy stuff, not the clear stuff. Interesting execution - worth trying for sure. I would sip again

4382.Review: Nose: nice cooked agave, barrel notes, light cooked pineapple, and smokeFlavor: cooked agave sweetness, hint of mezcla, wood notes, minerals, nice light mouth feel Finish: medium with the floral notes of white pepper

4384.Review: A clean, straw colored blanco. Nose:   Big saucy, sweet and spicy notes immediately jump to the forefront. Baked pineapple upside down cake, comes to mind: The richness of slow cooked pineapple, melted butter & crumbs, caramelizing brown sugar, allspice and cinnamon. An additional smokey pepper note and hints of vanilla creaminess.  Fresh cut orange roses.   A faint smell of attic dust.  A bit of cider. Just the faintest suggestion of Mezcal funkiness, campfire smoke and wood influence at this stage. Flavor:  White pepper and cinnamon heat blast out of the starting gates and refuse to back off. But the heat is a perfect foil to the fruit, agave, vanilla, anise, almond and salted melted butter - making for a rich and oily palate experience. In the mouth, more than in the nose, you find some its Mezcal heritage (having spent 28 days in a Don Amado Mezcal barrel).  Then further stabilized in Stainless Steel for 30 days. Finishing impressions:  Some minerals, grassiness and floral sensations show late in the finish. A lot of sweetness for 24 Brix agave - I have to think the barrels contributed to this.  On the one hand, this is a bold, brash and feisty sip. On the other hand, this is a silky, suave and easy sipper. A great collaboration.

4385.Review: Lo primero que resalta es el tenue color pajizo resultado del reposo de 28 días en barricas usadas en mezcal espadín Don Amado. NARIZ: muy sutil ahumado, menor al que se podía encontrar en el cascahuin aniversario; arcilla, pimienta, flor de azhar, agave crudo, ciruela amarilla, menta.BOCA: aquí si hay un buen golpe a mezcal, se siente el agave espadín, se confirma el sabor terroso, picante, la pimienta

4386.Review: Got that light smoke to it that could make it an excellent “gateway drug” into the world of mezcal?   A nice break from your routine of blancos perhaps?  It’s a bit expensive but it’s from an honest, quality producer and it’s a specialty tequila after all.

4387.Review: Are you F’ing serious? If This isn’t the best value on a tequila/mezcal… I don’t know what is. I get a tinge of smoke, with an agave punch that has an amazing mouth feel. It’s worth the price of admission just for the mouth feel alone. Well done. I guess I’m going to have to buy a few more bottles. If you haven’t already tried it… do yourself a favor and do so.

4388.Review: Big color difference between Lote 43 and 77, but the aroma and taste are amazing in both. Very unique, with the subtle influence of mezcal. More smoke in the 43 than the 77. Overall, The perfect influence as I keep going back…Lote 77 after opening/setting might be some of the best tequila I’ve had. Creamy, and the perfect amount of heat. I’ll buy ever bottle I ever come across

4389.Review: We raved about this release 18 months ago, loving its marked earthiness and mild smoke, along with the signature sweet cooked agaves notes from Cascahuin. An delicious historical Blanco that we continue to enjoy.  Very well recommended.  Cheers.

4390.Review: A Little too peppery for my liking. Only had a small sample. Will have to revisit.

4391.Review: Bottled on February’2021. Nose has a touch of smoke that disappears after 10 minutes in the glass. On the palate a mix of a touch of smoke with the sweetness of cooked agave with a touch of vanilla and black pepper, good sweetness and acidity balance. Finish is medium to long but the touch of vanilla throws this blanco off a little bit.

4393.Review: tasting notes from 2011 need to revisit and update

4394.Review: The rest in mezcal barrels yields a deep, vibrant aroma with a satisfying smoky finish.

4395.Review: Bottle: Lot 43Appearance: Very pale strawNose: Cooked agave, black pepper, smoke, charred pineapple, baking spice, earth, minerality…really unique and enticing nosePalate: Cooked agave, smoke, black pepper, cinnamon, vanilla, charcoal, butter, minerality, cider, tobacco, anise, earth, oak, alcohol…warm with good flavor, but a bit mutedFinish: Long, with lingering smoke, butter, alcohol, and earth flavorsOverall: A very good and unique tequila. I really like mezcal and was hoping for a lot more influence than was present. The flavors were all great, but a bit muted. I agree with the other reviewers, this would be a great sipper to pair with a cigar.

4396.Review: So much agave all the way through! The hint of smoke is a perfect match with the sweet juice. If you enjoy sipping blancos this is a must buy! It’s a bit expensive comparative to other amazing blancos, but worth it because it’s such a unique tequila.

4397.Review: The influence of the mezcal barrel adds a pleasing smokey accent to this earthy blanco.

4398.Review: High notes of mezcal, good taste, a bit harsh on the finish. It’s a unique experience tequila that pairs well with a cigar.

4399.Review: Initial agave sweetness on the tongue.  Then some butter turning to a nice peppery heat.  Earthy mint finish.  The smoke is extremely subtle on this.

4400.Review: As soon as I smelled… mind blown Another great product from 1123

4401.Review: On the nose it has a pleasant agave with a touch of smoke. On the palette it has mineral mushroom into a citrus heat. Hated it with ice, recommend with neat only

4402.Review: ArteNOM 1123 blanco ($58-$60 @ Ferment and Still) is a unique blanco that it is rested in Mezcal barrels. This produces a depth to the blanco that is hard to replicate. It's a real stunner. Nose: Delicate and dry with a flavorful sweet and savory balance.  Light semi-sweet cooked agave breaks ahead of the clay-earthiness. Then comes a touch of light smoke, dry sage and lemongrass, roasted pineapple fruit, white pepper, and faint traces of barrell oak. Very surprising. This is tequila artistry at its finest.Taste:   Oily and semi-sweet with a layer of savory smoke and charred hay.  Cooked agave, butter, and black pepper up front.  The mid palate brings some cinnamon, citrus .Finish:  Medium to long with with nice fill of smoke, pepper, and cinnamon.

4403.Review: Background on my experience with tequila - I’m definitely not an expert in tequila, but decent enough to distinguish between quality drinks from junk. I drink Scotch mostly, with a mix of cognac, cachaça, rum, and other liquor. I tend buy in the $50-$120 range. I met a gentleman who taught me a bit about higher quality tequila. He claimed he owns a large collection, containing bottles close to $2K.1123 - We met at a local distributor. He suggested the 1123, among other tequilas in that price range as an intro into the “more affordable tequilas,” for what that’s worth. I think they are all excellent tequilas, in my humble opinion, but the 1123 floats to the top. You get a lot for what you pay.I’ll keep updating this review as my experience improves.

4404.Review: great on the nose, agave forward with hi ts of citrus, roasted pineapple and tones of smoke..nice oily mouthfeel. peppery and sweet with that typical Cascahuin minerality. im getting the roasted taste of maiz and peanuts. a slight lactic undertone with a bouquet of wild flowers... the finish is medium long, betting an extra ripened mangoes and a yeasty tone.. like a sweet sour bread. soo different and yet still holds that 1123 DNA.. i love this.

4405.Review: Rich agave and citrus on the nose with lingering smoke. Smoky favors with rich agave, lime zest and vanilla. Great long finish of pepper and smoked agave. Well balanced and quite approachable. This is a winner.

4406.Review: Spicy, hint of smoke, nice mouth feel. Flavor not very complex. Slight burn on finish.Aged in mezcal barrels. Agave flavor is compromised. More mezcal than Blanco.I can see how this would appeal to some, just not my cup of tea.

4407.Review: Sweet with bright flavors and a beautiful smoky taste.  Great mouth feel and minerality. This is really impressive.

4408.Review: Such a nice light straw color with the perfect amount of cooked agave and spicy/pepper on the nose. The flavor continues with pepper and some smoke yet it is creamy. A nice mouth feel.  The finish has more pepper and agave.  This is wonderful stuff.  The price is great.  There is no need to buy over priced blancos.

4409.Review: Whoa! I did not expect that! Beautiful aroma - slight sweetness, slight smokiness, soft cooked agave. The taste follows suit, with a nice buttery mesquite/agave flavor. It's like a subtle tasty mezcal. Awesome!

4410.Review: I like Cascahuin and was expecting a similar taste profile.  I was surprised by the difference presented with the nose and taste.  Very unique Blanco with a rich, thick mouth feel.  A lot of pepper, spice, and a slight smokiness.  Good amount of heat, with multiple flavors that are hard for me to pinpoint. I like to smell the glass after it’s empty, and I get a smoky scent almost like your clothes smell after sitting around a campfire.

4411.Review: value value value! this is a great tasting blanco. Artenom and Cascahuin really came together on this one and crushed it out of the ballpark! my price point is $55 on this exquisite refreshing complex tequila. this blanco was slightly aged 28 days a lunar cycle in previously used brandy and mezcal barrels. Plenty of agave on the nose and palate and long finish any great tequila should have. so easy to sip no burn or heat. still plenty of blanco traits like citrus grassy and peppery earthy notes. Orange peel, honey and smokey ash, this came out more once I let it open up. Many more nuanced flavors and aromas. Seemed to have no end. my hats off to the Rosales family and Artenom.

4412.Review: Aroma is agave forward with light caramel, fruit, floral, and apple, undertones.Flavor is lightly oaked agave and mineral/vegetal. Have had 43%'s before but this one bites a little more early on and heat lingers past the swallow longer than flavor does. Still very enjoyable and a nice unique difference for a Blanco with the rested wood touch.

4413.Review: lote 43. light straw color due to resting in mezcal barrels for 28 days. 43% ABVaroma makes it up to the nose as soon as it's poured. mom's upside down pineapple cake for sure hits first. mineral, wet cement, earth, butter. hint of ash.complexity of flavor. cooked agave, baked pineapple, baked ham (yes), wet cement, butter, cinnamon, pepper. anise and/or licorice sensation on the tongue. a bit of a mezcal feel. ash on the tongue as well, which develops during the somewhat long (but not intense) finish. Jake Lustig and ArteNOM hits another Home Run with their Hall of Fame lineup

4414.Review: Nice buttery Blanco with notes of cooked agave, smoke, green chile peppers, peaches, papayas, mangoes, oranges, anise, cinnamon, salted caramel, butterscotch, and papyas

4415.Review: light golden color. sweet roasted agave earthy smoky baking spices pepper. light caramel citrus olives buttery artenoms best blanco

4416.Review: Lot 43; Purchased the bottle understanding the story. Although, I am a fan of the brand, this bottle just doesn’t strike a chord with me. Mid palate, I can’t get past the notes of what I’m unable to describe. I’ll attempt another rating soon, hoping to properly describe. Just not my cup of tea. I am very agave forward, blanco oriented at this time. Tried again (5/22) not a fan. Did I read correctly? Aged in mezcal barrel? That’s the reason I don’t like it. Too much “Jamaican Funk” for me.

4417.Review: rich and earthy but well integrated and subtle. fruit notes are lingering under the roasted agave flavor.

4418.Review: Nose: char and weight, but also floral - mostly hibiscus? It smells pastoral. Some bell pepper, too. Flavor: there's a lovely campfire like char straight through, probably from the mescal barrels. But in addition to the floral notes, there's some brine here, more like olives than the seaside. Citrus as well, which isn't on the nose; somewhere between lime and orange. For the amount of char, it's much lighter than you might expect, though it does thicken up a bit on the palate. This guy is a real easy sipper. Finish: Quick, not overstaying its welcome; there's more spice, maybe habanero, here than before. This stuff is really tasty and approachable for how interesting it is, like a cheery friend with an alt aesthetic. It's the sort of thing that I'll drink in the late afternoon or early evening on a summer day, with the light beginning to moderate, with some cool and fun people who want to nerd out on some spirits stuff.

4419.Review: Unbelievably unique. Tropical fruit, balanced richness with notes of butterscotch and caramel (Spanish brandy barrels were an excellent choice), buttery flavor/mouthfeel, and just enough smoke. Prefer this type of flavor combination over that of a cristalino.

4420.Review: Super nice tasting with a more than a hint of mezcal that lasts . Butter & smoke , sweet agave & pepper. Another score for ArteNOM !

4421.Review: Aroma - minerals, smoke, pepper Flavor - roast agave, minerals, earth, butterFinish - smooth with a nice warmth, butter and smoke lingers Just the right amount of Mezcal flavor which is minimal but adds a unique dimension!

4422.Review: Aroma is complex with a nice smokiness. Flavor is also complex for a blanco. You can tell it was aged in mezcal barrels. Smooth finish. Hard to believe it’s a blanco.

4423.Review: It’s so different it’s good. Smell of agave and earthiness. Taste more like mezcal than expected great agave,floral, earthiness taste. But not over powering.  Strong pepper in the middle and a long finish. Very very good. Can pour a glass and enjoy every sip but not something you’ll drink to fast fast.

4424.Review: In love with this blanco! Aroma is a  very inviting mix of cooked agave, pepper, and a hint of sweetness. Flavor is similar but add a touch of smoke and earth from the ex-mezcal barrels used. If you like mezcal you'll be intrigued by this blanco, if you don't like mezcal you'll be intrigued by this blanco! Very hard to put down!

4425.Review: Pretty sure this is the highest rating I’ve given on TMM. It’s a perfect marriage of what I love about mezcal AND tequila! Hard to put it down.

4426.Review: The aroma will leave you happy for hours, sweet and smooth to the noseThe flavor is peppery with agave.The finish leaves a nice subtle heat.This is yet another wonderful tequila from Artenom!Aged in Mezcal and Brandy barrels gives this a wonderful reposado color.

4427.Review: As someone who is often offended by aged Mezcal, I was particularly worried about the presence of possibly too much Don Amado Mezcal barrel influence in this expression. Not necessarily to my surprise though, The Rosasles family and Jake Lusting knocked this out of the park! ArteNOM Selección de 1123 Blanco Histrórico packs the classic Cascahuín character with a bit more layers, body, depth, and overall complexity. The purity of the Los Valles agaves really shines loud and clear, from nose to finish. I find the barrel to mainly add a bit more earthiness. This is a beautifully balanced aged Tequila that showcases prime agave selection and intuitive craftsmanship working in harmony.

4428.Review: Love the mezcal touch with barreling!

4429.Review: Great artesanal tequila, agave flavor with a small hint of wood and tiny smokiness. Reminds me a lot the Chascahuin Tahona Blanco.Excelente tequila artesanal, agave cocido con un toque de madera y un ligero sabor ahumado. Sabor artesanal. Me recuerds mucho al Cascahuin Tahona Blanco.

4430.Review: Just picked this up at OTT. Excited for this twist on a blanco tequila. Color is like very light reposado. Aroma is strong and different than most blancos. Lots of cooked, bright agave but also some dark earth aroma. In a flute there is noticeable alcohol and hint of smoke. Also a hint of the cement from fermentation. Taste is strong with sweet agave. Definite smoke in the mouth but not overpowering. Tingly pepper on the tongue and throat. Finish is my favorite part. Really long lasting and holds on to many of the aromas and flavors. The hint of smokey espadin is noticeable and good. Overall this is unique, cool and very tasty. It definitely is strong in taste and needs time for exploration.

4431.Review: NOM 1417|Wow! What a surprise. It was made in at NOM 1417 and has been stored exceptionally well. Sadly, it is no longer made at this distillery. I'm guessing from the laser coding it was bottled in 2004. The nose is light, but still has a haunting good aroma. The mid palate is super smooth. I mean really nice. The finish starts out hinting to roasted agave, the picks up a little warm heat. Just enough to make you cry because this is your only bottle. This is a gem and a true treasure bottle. I hope you get the he chance to taste it.

4433.Review: Nose:   There is a warm, vibrant blend of oak and spice upon opening. Followed by rich agave notes, the unmistakable fragrance of peachy fruitiness, and creaminess. Flavor:   Flavors follow the aromas: creamy, barrel spiciness with a pepper kick. Very pleasing mouth feel. Kind of like sitting down to a decadent dessert of peach custard, drizzled with vanilla and toffee.

4434.Review: Finally able to taste the last Unique product. A non medallion bottle meaning a 2nd or 3rd release, this anejo has some of the creme brulee of the XA, just not as evident until sitting for 8 to 10 minutes. Sad these are .375, happy they exist at all.

4435.Review: Great stuff only available in Asia. It didnt go down like a mixto at all!

4436.Review: Bottled in Singapore. Interesting story behind the brand which can be found with a quick google search. Drinks a lot like Cimarron blanco but at a slightly higher proof. Nose: Nice sweet cooked agave with some black pepper. After letting it rest I noticed some light vanilla which I really enjoyed. Palate: cooked agave which starts with hints of sweetness but not overwhelming. Finishes with a little bite of alcohol from that 42.5% abv and some black pepper as well. Medium body, probably would be great in a cocktail but still holds up as a tasty sipper.

4437.Review: Aroma: Bright cooked agave, alcohol since it’s 42.5%, vanilla Taste: gives me Pura Sangre vibes with a touch of wood - does this sit in wood for a bit? Tastes like 1146, peppery, little alcohol kiss since it’s higher proof Finish: warming, mineral - oak (I swear this rests in barrels, tell me I’m wrong)

4438.Review: Cherries, red fruit on the nose. Nice barrel notes in the mouth, spice and oak present along with good bourbon presence from the aging barrel. A somewhat older bottle this juice still has a kick from alcohol which provides a good numbing finish which resolves to agave pepper on the tongue. Good juice

4439.Review: The nose is not very dominant. It releases most of its flavor upon sipping. The finish is mostly made up from the barrel.  There is little flavor from the agave.  The result is a very smooth tequila, but has no distinguishing characteristics.

4440.Review: On the nose, agave but definitely some ethanol. Expected for a higher proof but noticeable. Some salinity, a little lime and minerality.On the palate, very sweet agave goodness. SomeCinnamon, minerality and a bit of a buttery note that is very enticing. Overall a delicious tequila. It’s a shame that 3G isn’t doing this as their normal blend, I’m already contemplating a case of this. Very delicious and well priced if you can find it around $40.

4441.Review: Finally got to it and it’s a keeper.  Double points for the price (Texas). A Sauza must for sure.

4442.Review: Nose:  Slightly muted aromas that must be coaxed out. Lime and orange zest. Minerals and earthiness. Thyme, mint and oregano. Agave in the front row too. Flavor:   Peppery attack. Buttery salinity. Gentle dosing of baking spices. Solid weight to the body.  A slightly nutty nuance, and a tiny bit of pepper bitterness at back of the tongue.

4443.Review: Not bad, didn’t love it. Soft earth? Little bit of heat on the finish

4444.Review: Earthy, lime, and agave on the nose. More agave, earth, pepper, and brine flavor. Nice creamy mouth with a medium finish and a pleasant tingly that tells you it’s tequila without overpowering (considering it’s 90 proof). No noticeable additives. Enjoyable sip! The story goes that this is made at Cascahuin and bottled at Sauza. I’ve seen retail prices on this from $35-70+ so assessing value is tricky. I got mine closer to the middle of that range.

4445.Review: Nose: cooked agave, natural sweetness, wet dirt, vegetal, citrus, lime, and some orange peel in the background Flavor: cooked agave, vegetal, agave sweetness, earthy, citrus, and some slight herbal flavor and a nice oily mouth feel Finish: is long and starts with some sweetness and moves to a peppery tingling

4446.Review: Excellent tequila, don't fall for the bullshit story. This is made by Cascahuin, and not Sauza, and it's double-distilled... not triple distilled. This is worth buying.

4447.Review: This is legit! Don’t let the brand name scare you off on this one.

4448.Review: Much better than their Blanco’s from the past. Better production methods makes this a pleasing Blanco to sip or mix. The price point of $35-$40 makes it a little tougher to approach as being a value Blanco.

4449.Review: I usually pass on TG products thanks to their production methods but the story behind this caught my attention. I also got this for a steal.Nose- loads of sweet agave, earth, pepperTaste- Cooked agave, pineapple, citrus, jalapeno, and some MineralityMouth Feel- fairly viscousFinish- The sweetness fades quick leaving some spicy pepper and alcohol. Value- this isn't fair since I got it so cheap. If it was $70 then no way. I paid much less.

4450.Review: Nose: Cooked agave and lime zest. Bright citrus, pine needles & muted minerals. Taste: Cooked agave and a vibrant mixture of strong citrus and jalapeño. Finish: The agave lingers while the jalapeño note turns into more of a black pepper. There’s a nice alcohol tingle from the higher proof. Overall this isn’t a complex Blanco but it’s also not a one note tequila either. The nose and taste like up nicely and it’s clean. It has a nice mouthfeel.

4451.Review: Purchased in January 2022 for USD73. Due to the distillery/brand capabilities, this price seems a bit high despite being a special release.Nose: some alcohol, but also vegetal and herbaceous. A bit muted, but it may be my glass and the temperature. Very rich agave presence likely due to it being still strength.Palate: quite viscous, minerality from the tahona, a slight sweetness from the agave. Characteristics from the aroma are equally present on the palate. Very herbal.Finish: a nice alcohol burn, agave sweetness, long lasting.

4452.Review: For some time, decades actually, La Perséverancia hasn't had the equipment on site to make something like this instead choosing to go all in with diffuser production for all lines made there. The story is this isn't made at NOM 1102, only bottled there which meets CRT rules. Value is added by bottling ergo it can be called Tres Generaciones. Enough of the chit chat, how's the tequila?Pretty good actually, though priced quite high, at least in WA for what essentially at this time is a one off orphan product for Sauza and it's 3G line. Interesting also is that this is labeled Vol.01. Will Vol.02 be a Reposado or simply a second release of this Plata? What about Vol. 3? Time will tell. Agave nose with some earth and hints of the 45% ABV. I have it from a good source that this is only 2X distilled and it tastes very solid with agave sweetness, creamy mouth feel and a nice bite from the 45%. The higher proof leads to an extended finish with the sweetness fading to some earth and mushroom and a well dispersed mouth tingle. Try some and post your thoughts.

4453.Review: It’s actually pretty good. Not sure about the price point, I was lucky and grabbed it for $35.

4454.Review: NOM 1123: Cascahuín export bottled at Sauza. Unique tequila that I had to search out. Glad I did, but at $69 it’s more expensive than I can get Cascahuín Tahona blanco for, so I won’t be purchasing again. Interesting conversation piece.

4455.Review: Nose clove spice citrus orange alcohol Taste delicious: anise licorice mint herbal citrus glycerin warm peppery finish 45% alcohol Recommend highly

4456.Review: I couldn’t decide why I like it I wanted to not like it but it is pretty good. Aroma is clean and fresh with a citrus zest and the cinnamon baking like spice is balanced nice overall for me clean and I like clean with complexity and this has it.The flavor again is nice the agave steps out in front then with a citrus pepper very straight forward with some power I like this one Yes gotta have this. The best sauna I ever had

4457.Review: Great agave on nose Nice hit of agave on 1st sup , you get some buttery notes, serious heat , white pepper on the finish . Oily mouthful hits right on the salivary glands. Would make a nice spicy libation.

4458.Review: Tres Generaciones (NOM 1102)Cenobio's Batch PlataNOSE: Fresh notes of buttery agave, citrus, vegetal, alcohol, mild spicy pepper, licorice, clove and mint.TASTE:  Proofed at 45% abv, which provides a nice heat, but does not negate the sweet buttery agave-forward flavor. Thick mouth feel with citrus-rind influences, earthy vegetals, cloves, pepper, licorice, and mint. On the finish, the heat tapers off quickly, leaving an agave/vegetal taste that. This is a decent old-skool production surprise from NOM 1102...  tahona/roller mill, stone/brick oven cooked, well water, fermented in stainless (sans fiber), and 2x copper pot distillation.

4459.Review: I love Cascahuin, so deducting a point or two for the misleading label. Cooked agave, pepper, and some citrus.

4460.Review: Putting aside the back story ( see Lou and Seattle). This is so much better than the 3G line.  The aroma/nose has citrus and agave. Very pleasant. The flavor is also mild with agave, citrus and maybe a hint of earthiness. A light touch of sweetness.  The finish follows this profile with a medium finish that leaves a pleasant lip tingle.  A very nice product and I am looking forward to the next (repo/anejo) expressions.

4461.Review: Very tasty! Nose is inviting with agave, citrus, cut grass.Flavor is very nice. Some complexity that evolves at the back of the tongue. Agave, earth, citrus. Slightly sweet after initial earthiness.Finish is wonderful. Long and lingering with citrus and a bit of afterburn.

4465.Review: Has a nice long finish no to heavy. The nose has cooked agave some pepper earth  and some fruit zest maybe orange. Overall a nice Tequila and a good value at around 31 dollars. Definitely worth a taste

4466.Review: very nice on the nose. earth, cooked agave, citrus,orange peel  some herbs. black pepper, dry peppers. I'm getting glazed pear ... 1st time. I'm getting a nice coating on the palate. oily great finish.. alot of agave, citrus, cane sweetness, lemon zest,  dry herbs and spices.nice bold and warm finish..am amazed by a tres generaciones.. it continues to surprise as it opens up.. great job with the oven cooked and Tahona crush...

4467.Review: Light heat, sweet agave, balanced. Finishes nicely

4468.Review: Bottle #107 Lote 2/21Nose:   Sweaty, cheesy. Herbal:  thyme, marjoram, oregano. Mint, cucumber and trace minerals. Sweet agave. Flavor:   Honey like sweetness/texture attack, with equal measure of white pepper heat. Cinnamon and cloves contribute to the pop of pepper heat. The Mezcal like lactic note mellows somewhat on the palate - but still in the forefront. A vague umami cracker flavor : sesame or caraway?Finish:   Cinnamon red hot candy and feisty pepper on the fadeaway, riding on a silky sweet agave wave.

4469.Review: Moderate viscosity carries a ton of flavor in this Espirítu Fuerte. Agave on the nose, agave on the palate and a long lingering finish with a fading natural roast agave sweetness make this an exceptional sip. I've said this once before regarding Criollo that products like this are like drinking distilled liquid agave with a great balance of heat, sweet, ethanol and pepper.

4470.Review: Nose: Stone, Mineral, Agave, Sweet, a little brine, dried fruit, smoke, citrus Taste: Fresh grass, lots of agave, peppery mineral

4471.Review: Nov 18, 2022tasted at distillery. such an amazing tour. good tequilas!I'm told u can only get this in Mexico so we purchased a couple bottles from the distillery to bring home

4472.Review: Funky on the nose, little funk on the taste, good finish.

4473.Review: Wow!!! This reminds me of Mezcal in aroma. That blue cheese aroma. Sounds weird but it’s the aroma I got. Earthy taste and peppery finish.

4474.Review: Agave sweetness comes through with some citrus on the front, and remains throughout. Interesting profile unlike any previous Ocho releases.

4475.Review: Subtle agave nose. Lots of agave on palate.  Minimal barrel notes, the agave shines here.  Subtle finish with minimal heat. It’s an easy sipper for sure. Price hurts the overall score.  It’s even better once it opens. Such an easy sipper. Top 5 easy for me. It’s a must try.

4476.Review: Very tannic compared to the usual Ocho Reposado which I attribute to the new barrels used once for Widow Jane Bourbon. It grew on me as I sipped more.

4477.Review: In my top 3 reposados. Cinnamon and mint on the nose. Incredible mouthfeel. Pecans. Cinnamon. Spearmint. Anise. Long and incredibly balanced finished. Another big winner from Ocho

4478.Review: Aroma is fantastic, with plenty of agave, fruity pineapple, wet earth, and cinnamon. Slight oak and more spice follow the flavor profile to join fruity agave notes. This 91 proof packs some punch and a mid-long finish, more for tequila lover’s than newbies. It may be lightly aged but the barrel is doing its job. Very nice combo on this excellent Reposado!

4479.Review: I thought was exceptional. Top 5 Reposado’s I have ever tasted. Light whiskey notes but the agave shines here. Delicious

4480.Review: Bottle #850145.5% ABVNose:   First pass before swirling:  Fruit, baking spice and light oak. Several swirls in, the individual fruits begin to reveal themselves: green pineapple, banana, passion fruit and sweet Crispin apples.  There is an alluring sour-sweet aroma…  Nose tingling minerals and a whiff of dry soil. A bold nutmeg, cinnamon, and green cardamom medley, marry with the fruit adding layered richness. Flavors:   Butterscotch, imbued with light oak barrel notes. The spirited spice medley frolics around the palate. Punchy black pepper slowly recedes and melds with the fruit and honeyed agave. Vanilla, hints of orange pith and dark berries. A little salinity and a mouth watering, buttery texture.  Trace tannins present.Finish:  Tenaciously holds on to the pepper and spicy elements through the finish - but with a creamy almond cream fade out.

4481.Review: Been on my watch shouts since release. Overpaid, but had to have it. Not disappointed, oak & apple on the nose. Cinnamon & butterscotch across the palate, slight pepper & agave on the backend. One of my favorite reposados! The only weakness is the price, if you can find it for $70 USD, it is a great value.

4482.Review: Off the nose you get that pepper right off, mixed with oak. On the Palate I get a sweet vanilla taste that goes well with the agave sweetness

4483.Review: Sweet agave, cinnamon, minerals and a hint of whiskey. Amazing reposado. Great price.

4484.Review: LOT  RLA-034WJ bottled on 30/08/2022.Color: very very pale yellow.Nose: vanilla, wood spices, cooked agave, alcohol almost unnoticeable.Palate: cooked agave sweetness, vanilla, wood spices, good balance, but the agave taste and aroma have been masked by the wood spice & vanilla notes.Finish is medium in length, vanilla, wood spice and light agave sweetness persists.

4485.Review: While I'm a huge fan of all Ocho products, this just wasn't my favorite. Those that are into whiskey will like this a lot and will disagree with my review. On the nose there's definitely agave, but there's also some barrel and spice notes, as well as alcohol that dominate the aroma. While this expression is not as high proof as their single barrel añejos, it smells and drinks a tad harsher.On the palate, I get an instant agave kick that is then overpowered by oak, bitter chocolate, spices, ginger, and alcohol. The finish is long.To me, the chemistry of the tequila and the bourbon barrels just wasn't there.

4486.Review: Pepper and Oak almost right away with subtle notes of Vanilla on the back.

4487.Review: Lot RLA-034WJ30/08/2022Bottle No. 38245.5% ABVDamn, this is outstanding.Initial nasal impact is warming with a slight prickle.Aroma keeps building as it opens up, leading with sweet cooked agave, crisp fall apple, limestone, baking spice, cinnamon, apricot, caramelized pineapple and rounded out with whiskey and fennel.Generous heat and a buttery mouthfeel.The sweet cooked agave still shines, as with all Carlos Camarena aged expressions. Add to that a healthy dose of baking spice, light oak, brine, pecans and orange with black pepper evenly sprinkled throughout.The long finish is amazing, highlighting the pepper, apricot and whiskey barrel notes while still staying very creamy.Overall impression is that the agave is still the star of the show. This reposado is clean, sharp and harmoniously balanced. An exceptional tequila. I bought this for $54, so my value rating was higher than most, but even at 75-100 bucks, this is a top reposado and should be in your glass.Very glad this particular bottle is my 300th rating on TMM.

4489.Review: Aroma of out of the horno cooked agave, brown sugar, leather, light spices. Flavor is sweet up front with brown sugar dissolving into agave, light oak, cinnamon, white pepper. Finish is a tad hot and comes as a suprise after such sweetness but aligns well. Very balanced, not over oaked, bourbon notes come out the more it opens both in the aroma and the flavor. Really nice and well done.

4490.Review: Purchased from 2 different stores. If could get under $100 value would increase. Special bottle though

4492.Review: This is an amazing pour. I love the sweetness, but not overly sweet. The barrel gives it a deep complexity. Not even a hint of ethanol. Perhaps the best repo I’ve ever tasted.

4493.Review: Very good, a little overhyped and overpriced but an interesting one to have on the shelf.Well balanced sweetness and agave, a little pepper and citrus. Finish is quite nice.Probably won’t buy another bottle at $120 but I will enjoy the rest of this one with friends.

4494.Review: A nice amount of barrel influence but the agave is still there. Can smell the minerality and taste the whiskey influence. Well done.

4496.Review: Loads of agave up front, a little oak, brine, vanilla, pepper, some alcohol (whiskey like), anise, maybe a light tart cherry, Very nice repo.  The more you drink the more flavorful it gets.

4497.Review: 500th tasting!  Let it breathe for 15 minutes, the agave aroma pushes through.  Cinnamon flavor with a peppery finish.  Interesting profile, more barreling than the traditional Ocho reposado (newer barrels?), the higher proof keeps the agave present throughout the tasting!

4498.Review: What a great way to hit my 300th rating!  It unfolded very nicely to produce complex aromas and spicy flavors. This repo is a treat!

4499.Review: The nose is very similar to other Ocho offerings. Agave upfront, cinnamon light fresh fruit and a hint of oak.Taste is cooked agave, cinnamon, sweetness is coming through similar to a fire ball. Hint of the barrel oak.Finish is outstanding, vegetal, cooked agave and a light lingering pepper.

4501.Review: Aroma: cooked agave, cinnamon, barrel spice, cloves. Taste: Tons of agave right off the bat, followed by earth, cinnamon, clove, and smoke. Long sweet finish. For $65 (Hi-Time Wine Cellars), this repo is a bargain. An amazing collaboration!!!

4502.Review: Compared to the regular 2022 el nacimiento, these barrels had more of a smoothing and mellowing effect, making this one an even easier sipper. Delicious!

4504.Review: Agave is the star here along with the wonderful aromas and flavors introduced by the barrels. This is a high proof blanco lovers ideal Reposado. Just the right amount of spicy, peppery, fruity aromas complimenting the agave. Super complex, buttery rich, pepper and cinnamon that lingers into a wonderful finish.  I have a couple of favorite Reposados, but this Widow Jane is the best I’ve had (so far).

4505.Review: Wow!! Such a delicious complex Reposado. It’s got that Ocho aroma 100%, ton of agave on the nose, so many baking spices, cinnamon, black pepper, I get a little bit of minerality with it. Nice long black pepper finish. It did not get shown up by the barrel at all. I’d say a top 3 Reposado for me.

4506.Review: This was exceptional, nice bourbon notes and cooked agave. The finish on this is amazing. Definitely in my top 3 of reposados I have tasted. The thought of an anejo version has me salivating.

4507.Review: An amazing Repo and collaboration with Window Jane. I get the slight sweetness of their standard repo with barrel notes of WJ. I’m not a whisker fan and this, IMO, has limited whiskey flavor - pure agave for me.This is my favorite repo atm and I’d like to see this remain in the TO line up vs one off collab. I have a big stash just in case it never gets produced again ;)

4508.Review: Nose: Fresh fruity agave, pineapple taste and very intense flavor.Taste: Very silky and delicious feeling that fill the palate of creamy and fresh agave flavor. Slight burn that complements the taste.Medium to long aftertaste, dry and herbal with a little afterburn.

4509.Review: Sad we canâ€™t get this anymore. They need to make an anniversary addition. From the same distillery as Ocho I believe. Vibrant, cooked agave, smooth, great finish.

4510.Review: Roast agave abounds on the nose and continues from first sip to finish. It has some bitterness at the end which for me holds this back as I prefer a more neutral or slight natural sweetness, especially with as much roast agave as this has on the nose and in great amounts in the mouth. Repeated nosing from a glencairn reveal some floral notes which remind me of carnations. It is the first day of Spring after all. 65th birthday review.

4511.Review: Amazingly clean and complex, this tequila is a treasure.

4512.Review: Aroma is relatively light/faint. Distinct vegetal/grassy notes with a slight background sweetness. Noticeable aromas of raw agave - fresh/clean versus sweet/toasted. "Old-school" blanco flavor with noticeable agave and clay/dirt alongside. Overall, very mild in all flavors. Nice, spicy finish is moderate in length.

4513.Review: Aroma: Very light and mellow. There is definite agave but there's also a slight sweet note. At first it was more towards vanilla but after time I start getting cinnamon.Flavor: This reminds me of a very traditional blanco. It's earthy with strong raw agave notes and a bit if clay. My only criticism is that's it's very light and almost feels a little watered down.

4514.Review: This is fantastic. Silky, big pepper, long finish.

4516.Review: What a delicious blanco!Wonderful nose of roasted agave, green grass, honey, citrus. Takes a bit to open up, but when it does, wow.Big roasted agave sweetness up front that gives way to a lovely interplay of serrano, mineral, lime zest, melon. Complex and dances on the tongue. Cool on the palate, with a nice heavy heavy mouthfeel.Exits quickly with more roasted agave.....but then.....wait.....more of that crisp green chili again. You think the finish is gone, but instead it just lingers with a faintittle sparkle. Great stuff. Long out of production, so might be hard to find, but if you come across some at less than secondary mkt prices, buy it all.

4517.Review: Distinctive stuff, let's call it a breakfast tequila!   Very light on the palate, but not without flavor, which favors citrus and floral notes over spice.     Hard to get now, impossible perhaps, but a worthy and distinctive effort.    Reminiscent in texture and body of Alacran.

4518.Review: Not much of a nose. Agave scent and flavor lacking.

4519.Tequila: Ocho Tequila 8/8/8 - Rancho El Carrizal Extra Añejo
4519.Review: Slightly disappointed as I expected better.  I find other Ocho XAs have the edge over this 888 at a lower price point.

4520.Tequila: Ocho Tequila 8/8/8 - Rancho El Carrizal Extra Añejo
4520.Review: Bottle 142 Barrel 03 Nose: Tropical Floral and Fruit, ripe peach, sweet agave, vanilla, hint of coffee, and light oakFlavor: creamy mouth feel, sweet agave comes through, honey, and butterscotch Finish: Long finish with light spice, agave, and some cedar.This is a very nice XA. I would serve this with desserts and would pair nicely with regular and chocolate creme brûlée, salted caramel butterscotch pudding, or chocolate mousse

4521.Tequila: Ocho Tequila 8/8/8 - Rancho El Carrizal Extra Añejo

4522.Tequila: Ocho Tequila 8/8/8 - Rancho El Carrizal Extra Añejo
4522.Review: Plenty of cooked agave in the aroma along with light caramel, fruit and a little citrus. The cooked agave is also present in the flavor but somewhat overwhelmed with baking spices and heat. There is also just a hint of caramel sweetness at the open before the spicy heat takes over. Long, warm finish. The 48.8 ABV on this one seems more hot than the 50.0 on the Alquimia and may be just a bit much for my taste.12-24-20197th Annual Xmas XA tasting

4523.Tequila: Ocho Tequila 8/8/8 - Rancho El Carrizal Extra Añejo
4523.Review: Bottle #5, Barrel 01Nose:   The aroma is special: round and comforting, but punchy. Tropical fruit, pineapple, peach and a floral note.  Vanilla, cardamom, coffee and light butterscotch. There is oak here and subtle cedar notes - but restraint has been given to respect the agave that still shines through. Flavor:   Silky, buttery smooth texture, but carries a potent spice zing. Citrus, green peppercorns, butterscotch. There is a dessert quality to this XA.   Similar to a rich Mexican flan?  At 48.8% ABV, this does not present “too hot”. But be warned, as easy as it is to sip, it will sneak up on you. Finish has staying power, with pepper and spice zip and offsetting creamy agave mouth feel.

4524.Tequila: Ocho Tequila 8/8/8 - Rancho El Carrizal Extra Añejo
4524.Review: Pitted fruit, raisin, and licorice oak aromas with slightly sweet agave, burnt caramel and honey flavors and a bright, pungent finish brought by the high proof (48.8%). A dry extra añejo that is not over-oaked, despite 8 years in the barrel. (I’ve always appreciated Ocho’s light touch when it comes to aging.) A tightly packed XA with a high-proof kick.

4525.Tequila: Ocho Tequila 8/8/8 - Rancho El Carrizal Extra Añejo
4525.Review: The color of this Extra Añejo is very light, which is a visual clue that it may still contain agave, not just oak. In this case, it does. Cooked agave, hay, dried fruit, tobacco and slight peach aromas. At 48.8% abv, the alcohol is also in the nose but isn’t overly aggressive. Alcohol doesn’t dominate the flavor at all, as I find this easy to drink. Cooked agave, molasses, and vanilla flavor. Really long cooked agave on the finish. Nicely done, not over-done.

4526.Tequila: Ocho Tequila 8/8/8 - Rancho El Carrizal Extra Añejo
4526.Review: Subtle aroma and refined taste.  I feel a little tangy alcohol feeling.  It might not be the Ocho that I imagine.

4527.Tequila: Ocho Tequila 8/8/8 - Rancho El Carrizal Extra Añejo
4527.Review: Stone fruit, perhaps dried peach or apricot on nose with vanilla hints…Slight Cognac on tongue…Terrific finish, layers of vanilla. A few minutes after swallow leaves a fantastic toast on tongue… velvety mouthfeel

4528.Tequila: Ocho Tequila 8/8/8 - Rancho El Carrizal Extra Añejo
4528.Review: Barrel No. 8. LOT 8EAS88A-B082008. Bottled 30/11/2018.Color is dark yellow.Nose: citrus, wood spiciness, earthiness, wet cement, menthol, light vanilla, cooked agave. Very light camphor wood notes. Palate: ethanol is present, vivid, slightly hot but when it dissipates, buttery wood spiciness, vanilla, earthiness, astringent from wood, cooked agave.Finish is medium long, menthol/ethanol and wood spiciness dominates, cooked agave is lightly perceived. Wood notes are too impregnating…

4529.Tequila: Ocho Tequila 8/8/8 - Rancho El Carrizal Extra Añejo
4529.Review: Bottle 143, Barrel 6The aroma of this tequila is probably the best I’ve experienced.  Potent vanilla, agave, oak, and a sweet smell of either fruit or floral (I’m not that good at identifying aromas).  Very spicy on the palate with some pleasant and expected heat.  Some oak bitterness that fades to a sweet vanilla, and agave that carries through to the finish.  This is a very generous gift from a really good friend, so I can’t rate the value.  I do realize this limited edition release is expensive.

4530.Tequila: Ocho Tequila 8/8/8 - Rancho El Carrizal Extra Añejo

4531.Tequila: Ocho Tequila 8/8/8 - Rancho El Carrizal Extra Añejo
4531.Review: The 8/8/8 will go down as a collector’s bottle.  The Camarena and Estes family planned this expression perfectly.  Oak and cooked agave provide the first notes and this is followed closely with caramel and citrus.  The balance of this tequila is exceptional and nothing short of what you would expect from NOM 1474.

4532.Tequila: Ocho Tequila 8/8/8 - Rancho El Carrizal Extra Añejo
4532.Review: Bottle 123, barrel 03. Very agave forward for an XA. A bit hot at 48.8%. Very long finish. Peppery. Quality juice, but overpriced due to limited production.

4533.Tequila: Ocho Tequila 8/8/8 - Rancho El Carrizal Extra Añejo
4533.Review: This is an amazing Tequila and would be worthy of a mid 90s if it wasn’t so pricey. I can’t believe that it’s been aged 8 yrs 8 mo and continues to retain significant roasted agave flavor.

4534.Review: Great XA for the price point. I prefer it over San Matias XA which I dont even like. Slight edge over Lidia De Toro XA for the best budget friendly XAs.

4535.Review: A great tequila  for the price. Not a popular brand. Not a pretty bottle. A great value for the price.

4537.Review: Deep amber color. A little medicinal upfront on the nose, gives way to dark cherry, candied fruit. Not a lot of agave. Sweet upon entry, cuts a bit thin and transitions to oak, spices and pepper. Quick finish.

4539.Review: Amazing aroma. Dried fruit, chocolate, subtle ripe peach. medium body and mouth feel. Some slight astringency. overall nicely done.

4540.Review: Same grievance as the other expressions, this just isn’t agave forward! Let me say this anejo smells fucking AMAZING, makes you want to dive right in and swim around. I taste bourbon from start to finish, a very yummy bourbon but unfortunately it’s not kept it’s pedigree from agave. Good finish that would pair nicely with a cigar, give it a whirl if you have the $.

4541.Review: Nose came in waves. 1st wave was heavy bourbon. Next wave was flowers, dried fruit and agave. 3rd was was baking spices, vanilla and fresh tropicals with a fading bourbon presence. Taste of vanilla, dark cherry, and bitter sweet chocolate. Followed by almonds, oak and heat. And a flavor that reminds me of grandma’s “hope chest”.  Hmmm. Revision #3:  2/22/2019 I still find a slightly off taste in the finish. Almost a varnish like note.

4542.Review: Picked this up in Cabo late in 2017. Nothing special the añejo is very bourbon forward on the nose and the palate. Nothing offensive but there are a lot of products in the market that taste similar.

4543.Review: agavesmooth barrel oak taste definitely recommend for a whisky or scotch drinker

4544.Review: This was vegetal and earthy medicinal.   We found it really didn’t even seem like tequila.  Odd plastic type aftertaste.  And for $110!?!?   Won’t happen again

4547.Review: Smells like whiskey and vanilla. Oaky. Smells better than it tastes. Acetone flavour.

4549.Review: Floral, vanilla and whiskey throughout the aroma and taste. Stronger first sip than expected but great finish. Very understandable why this tequila has a big following in Mexico and beyond. Great flavour value for money.

4550.Review: AROMA - Pronounced notes of buttery vanilla, spices, oranges, medium oakyness, and creamy caramel along with the sweetness of dried fruits.PALATE - Creamy mouth, good alcohol heat without being too hot or overwhelming. The aromas announce themselves on your palate with the addition of apricots and peaches, some light pepper and anise, and cinnamon. It all finishes quite nicely with a sweet oaky honey flavor.

4551.Review: All the notes you would expect in an anejo with whiskey notes and floral aroma. Pleasant but not overly impressive.

4552.Review: Just excellent “unknown” tequila. So smooth with great agave, oak and cherry flavors. Paid $35

4553.Review: Strong alcohol flavor.  Too sweet.  Not an expert on distinguishing additives but I could tell the next day.

4554.Review: Very smooth with little to no bite. Caramel vanilla forward with oak barrel notes for sure on the finish. A great price for a solid Anejo.

4555.Review: Pleasant oaky smell, a little toned down but pleasant taste. Great peppery finish. Overall, very nice and balanced Anejo.

4556.Review: To me this taste like scotch

4557.Review: Aroma:Strong oaky presence (wonder if they used a heavy or full heavy char), sweet notes: vanilla, caramel, molasses, maple syrup. Dried fruits/raisins. Light agave. Flavor:Whiskey, barrel spice, butter (texture), dates (that was first time I detect that fruit flavor on a tequila, really liked that!). Chocolate and nutty notes in the profile. Not a lot of agave, medium finish/feel, bourbon experience that it might be a great starter for whiskey lovers. Great price!

4558.Review: great flavour and very smooth finish

4561.Review: aroma: caramel, butter, orangetaste: citrus, agave

4562.Review: I loved the body and the smokiness of this añejo tequila. I first had a shot then I enjoyed it in a Paloma. I highly recommend!

4563.Review: Vanilla and a little whiskey on the noseVery oaky, vanillaAgave. Very sweet. Smooth with agave finish.

4565.Review: whiskey, barrel spice, stone fruit up front on aroma. agave comes in a bit later. vanilla and sharp citrus follow in behind.whiskey soaked oak, stone fruit with a brightness of citrus and mild heat balance it out on the flavor. dark, overripe cherry develops on a medium+ finish. maybe some mild baking soda comes through late on aftertaste. would not consider it agave forward, but an interesting sipper, especially at a $35-39 price point. again, the plastic/wax seal around synthetic cork is annoying. still a bottle worth having

4566.Review: vanilla and buttery, not too spicy

4567.Review: Anejo in the glass tonight. Nice gold colour but I like mine a little darker. Could be smoother on the finish but still very good. Will buy again.

4568.Review: I should have just paid more mind to the reviews. The whiskey on this is the dominant factor. $45 down the tube. The reposado was good but a little dull so I figured this would be right on. Nope.

4569.Review: Aroma of toasted caramel and molasses. Vanilla-caramel flavour evolves into an exquisite long pepper-cherry finish. Nice!!!

4570.Review: Was ok, tasted much like scotch whiskey. Maybe european oak casks used.

4571.Review: Awesome whisky-like Anejo.  Lots of butterscotch and caramel, with a bit of smoke.  A bit peppery on the finish, which is nice and long. This is a terrific bargain in Playa del Carmen.

4572.Review: I like this tequila. good sipping tequila. Has a spicy finish. I like the taste.

4573.Review: This is my mixer for espresso martinis.

4574.Review: Found this bottle at Costco for 30 bucks which is a heck of a deal for this anejo ,nose - vanilla, oak ,cooked agave honey ,on the palate oak ,caramel, black pepper, vanilla bit of alcohol ,its smooth on the way down ..

4576.Review: Subtle nose up front. Starts off a little sweet with a cooked agave flavor. aged oak finish.

4577.Review: Meredith: mmmmm doesn’t taste like tequila but good.Might almost be bourbon.

4578.Review: Spice leather almond caramel vanilla nose.Silky mouthfeel, heat vanilla oak, almond caramel taste. Roasted agave finish? A hint of anise on the nose?

4579.Review: Not as sweet as Añejos usually are. Aroma too alcohol like, nice body and taste and finish is good. Drier finish and oaky flavour

4580.Review: Lots of honey and caramel on the noseStrong bite with smooth finish, light mouth feel Lots of oakiness and agave characteristics, finished with some spice Yum!

4581.Review: Sweet smell, very intense bite to it. Finish is left in mouth

4582.Review: Aroma of oak and agave. I taste the agave here, there is a bourbon presence, but it is still an enjoyable spirit and definitely a tequila. It has a bite, but alcohol flavor does not overwhelm. Good choice, it didn’t break the bank. Nice enough presentation. Recommend.
